title: Honest-Majority Hashpower Assumption
summary: Bitcoin assumes a majority of active hashpower follows protocol-valid chain selection over time.
details: Proof-of-work security requires that adversarial hashpower remains below a sustained majority threshold; otherwise censorship and reorg capabilities increase materially.
impact: If broken, deep reorg resistance and censorship resistance degrade.
mitigations: Use confirmation-depth policies proportionate to value-at-risk.

title: Network Propagation Assumption
summary: Bitcoin assumes timely, sufficiently connected propagation of blocks and transactions across peers.
details: When propagation quality degrades, stale rates and attack windows can increase, affecting miner incentives and finality confidence.
impact: Higher stale/orphan rates and improved conditions for withholding or isolation attacks.
mitigations: Use robust relay infrastructure and diverse peering.
Stay updated with modern networking improvements.
Monitor unusual latency and fork-rate signals.

title: Economic Incentives Assumption
summary: Bitcoin assumes most participants follow economically rational strategies aligned with long-term network value.
details: Miner and node behavior is guided by expected profitability, cost structure, and market confidence. Incentive misalignment can create temporary attack opportunities or policy tensions.
impact: If incentives diverge sharply, security margins and user expectations can be stressed.
mitigations: Transparent fee market signals and healthy competition.
Diverse ecosystem participants and independent validation.
Operational risk controls for high-value settlement.

title: Cryptographic Assumption
summary: Bitcoin security assumes SHA-256 and signature schemes remain computationally secure against practical adversaries.
details: Proof-of-work and transaction authorization rely on hash preimage resistance and signature unforgeability. If these assumptions fail at scale, consensus and ownership guarantees are threatened.
impact: Potential breakage of chain security or key-ownership integrity.
mitigations: Planned upgrade pathways through BIPs if needed.
